subject: Re: [junit] assertEquals(Object, Object)
msgSnippet: ... Yes, looking at the version in CVS it is this: static public void assertEquals(String message, Object expected, Object actual) { if (expected == null &&
messageBody:
On Fri, May 10, 2002 at 01:01:15PM -0600, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
> I believe assertEquals(o1, o2) essentially does this:
>
> if( o1 == null ) {
> assertTrue(o1 == o2);
> }
> else {
> assertTrue(o1.equals(o2));
> }

Yes, looking at the version in CVS it is this:

static public void assertEquals(String message, Object expected, Object actual) {
if (expected == null && actual == null)
return;
if (expected != null && expected.equals(actual))
return;
failNotEquals(message, expected, actual);
}

Some time ago on the German XP-list there was the suggestion, that
assertEquals might additionally check hashCode(). Thus changing the
second if-statement above to

if (expected != null && expected.equals(actual)) {
if (expected.hashCode() != actual.hashCode())
failDifferentHashcodes(message, expected, actual);
else
return;
}

Motivation: In the doc to Object.hashCode() it is stated:

# If two objects are equal according to the equals(Object) method,
then calling the hashCode method on each of the two objects must
produce the same integer result.

Earlier you wrote:
> assertEquals() checks two objects for equality according to the equals()
> method. It is not designed to test the validity of your equals() method;
> quite the opposite, it relies on the correctness of your equals() method.

The change above to also check hashCode, would be a test of the
validity of equals(). But I consider it a feature, not a problem, even
though it is not a sufficient test.

--
marko schulz
